diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: SLE can lead to a wide range of complications including neurological symptoms (e.g., delirium), autoimmune hemolysis, and potentially serositis which can manifest as pericarditis, pericardial effusion, and pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: While primarily affecting joints, rheumatoid arthritis can also cause systemic manifestations including pleural and pericardial effusions. Autoimmune mechanisms can also lead to hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.reason: This condition can feature autoimmune attacks on various tissues. While delirium is less common, pericardial and pleural effusions can occur due to scleroderma's impact on connective tissue.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.reason: This disease combines features of several autoimmune diseases including SLE and scleroderma, potentially leading to a mixture of symptoms such as those described.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: This rare autoimmune disorder combines immune thrombocytopenia and autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Associated systemic inflammation might indirectly cause effusions and delirium.

diagnoses.name: Drug-Induced Lupus
diagnoses.reason: Certain medications might trigger symptoms mimicking SLE, including serositis (e.g., pericarditis) and autoimmune hemolysis.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.reason: Typically caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it can occasionally lead to hemolytic anemia, pericarditis, and neurological symptoms including delirium.

diagnoses.name: Viral Pericarditis
diagnoses.reason: Certain viral infections can directly cause pericarditis and pericardial effusion. Secondary autoimmune responses or systemic effects might lead to other symptoms noted.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reason: Certain types of lymphoma could lead to autoimmune hemolysis, neurological symptoms, pericardial and pleural effusions as paraneoplastic phenomena.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reason: This inflammatory disease can affect any part of the body but mostly targets lungs and lymph glands. It can cause pleural and pericardial effusions and potentially autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses: Evans syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, if other causes of psychosis are ruled out)
Infectious diseases (e.g., tuberculosis, bacterial, viral, or fungal infections)

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT)
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation and can present with telangiectasias, easy bleeding, and arteriovenous malformations in organs that might lead to symptoms like chest pain.

diagnoses.name: Osler-Weber-Rendu Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Another name for Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia, highlighting its hereditary nature and presenting symptoms like telangiectasias and occasional cysts in the liver or other organs along with easy bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Von Hippel-Lindau Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder causing cysts and benign tumors to grow in the body, including the brain which could lead to hypersensitivity reactions and other symptoms depending on the cysts' locations.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: While primarily known for its impact on the female reproductive system, in some cases, it can lead to various systemic symptoms, including chest pains and possibly leading to skin manifestations although less commonly associated with telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders affecting connective tissues and can present with easy bleeding, chest pains due to cardiovascular involvements, and less commonly, cysts.

diagnoses.name: Familial Mediterranean Fever
diagnoses.description: An inherited condition that often presents with chest pain, hypersensitivity reactions and can sometimes lead to the development of cysts due to complications such as amyloidosis.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by an abnormal accumulation of mast cells in the skin and other parts of the body, leading to hypersensitivity reactions, and in some cases, telangiectasias and symptoms like chest pain.

diagnoses.name: Cystic Fibrosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to the production of thick, sticky mucus that can cause cyst formation in the lungs and other organs, potentially leading to chest pain due to lung involvement.

diagnoses.name: Gardner's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A variant of familial adenomatous polyposis that in addition to polyps in the colon, can present with cysts, easy bleeding, and various other extracolonic manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by tumors that produce excessive levels of gastrin, leading to ulcers and easy bleeding. While less directly related, patients might experience chest pain as part of the peptic ulcer symptoms.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue, leading to rashes, easy bruising, and potentially miscarriages among its varied manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder associated with blood clots, miscarriages, and may present rash. It's often considered in the differential diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels, which can cause rashes, easy bruising due to vessel fragility, and various systemic symptoms depending on the organ systems involved.

diagnoses.name: Dermatitis Herpetiformis
diagnoses.description: A chronic skin condition causing blisters, rashes, and easy bruising, often associated with gluten sensitivity.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder causing a low platelet count, leading to easy bruising and bleeding. Rashes in the form of petechiae or ecchymoses are common.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schonlein Purpura
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the small blood vessels that can cause rashes, abdominal pain, and kidney issues. It can lead to easy bruising and is more common in children.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Liver Disease
diagnoses.description: Liver dysfunction can lead to a wide array of symptoms including easy bruising (due to impaired production of clotting factors), dysgeusia, and sometimes hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Insulinoma
diagnoses.description: A tumor of the pancreas that produces excess insulin, leading to hypoglycemia. While not directly related to rashes or easy bruising, the systemic effects of hypoglycemia can broadly affect health.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which the adrenal glands don't produce enough hormones. This can cause hyperpigmentation (which may be misinterpreted as rashes), hypoglycemia, and has been associated with autoimmune-related infertility.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. It can present with dermatitis herpetiformis, a type of rash, and may contribute to miscarriage or fertility issues.

diagnoses.name: Acute Bronchitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the bronchial tubes, symptoms include cough, wheezing, and possibly fever and chest discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction that causes sneezing, congestion, runny nose, and sinus pressures. It can be associated with epistaxis due to frequent nose blowing and can exacerbate wheezing in asthmatic patients.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your airways narrow and swell and may produce extra mucus. This can make breathing difficult and trigger coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath.

diagnoses.name: Upper Respiratory Infection (URI)
diagnoses.description: A contagious infection of the upper respiratory tract, which may cause cough, congestion, fatigue, and sometimes epistaxis from irritation.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs. Symptoms include breathing difficulty, cough, mucus (sputum) production and wheezing.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of blood-forming tissues, hindering the body's ability to fight infection. It can cause leukocytosis, fatigue, frequent infections, and other symptoms like epistaxis due to platelet issues.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: Anxiety disorder may not directly cause the other symptoms but could exacerbate or contribute to obsessive-compulsive behavior, and indirectly affect conditions like asthmatic breathing or coughs.

diagnoses.name: Panic Disorder
diagnoses.description: A psychiatric condition that can cause episodes of intense fear or discomfort, sometimes leading to real physiological symptoms like shortness of breath, coughing, or wheezing.

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by unwanted, intrusive thoughts and repetitive, compulsive physical or mental acts. It doesn't directly cause the listed physical symptoms but could be present concurrently.

diagnoses.name: Nasal Polyps
diagnoses.description: Benign growths on the lining of nasal passages or sinuses that can lead to breathing problems, loss of smell, and frequent infections that could present symptoms like cough or epistaxis.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Connective Tissue Disease (such as Rheumatoid Arthritis or Sjögren's Syndrome)
Acute Viral Infections (e.g., Epstein-Barr Virus, HIV)

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. These excess cells thicken the blood, slowing its flow, and can cause complications such as increased risk of blood clots. Symptoms often include headache, dizziness, itching, and vision problems. Polycythemia Vera can lead to an increased susceptibility to infection.

diagnoses.name: Carcinoid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs in some individuals with carcinoid tumors. These tumors release chemicals into the bloodstream, such as serotonin, leading to various symptoms including flushing, diarrhea, wheezing, and in some cases, ulcers in the gastrointestinal tract.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases characterized by high blood glucose levels over a prolonged period. Symptoms can include polyuria, polydipsia, weight loss, and increased risk of infections. Glycemic lability, or fluctuations in blood sugar levels, is a key challenge in diabetes management.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare primary immunodeficiency disorder characterized by an inability of phagocytes to kill certain types of bacteria and fungi, leading to increased susceptibility to infections. Patients might not present directly symptoms like polycythemia or ulcers but have a broad range of clinical manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by the accumulation of mast cells in the skin and/or internal organs. Symptoms can include flushing, gastric ulcers, diarrhea, and an increased risk of infection due to immune system involvement.

diagnoses.name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition where ulcers form on the stomach lining, the small intestine, or the esophagus. Symptoms include stomach pain, nausea, and not directly linked but can be associated with systemic symptoms in complex cases.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. It can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, potentially leading to increased susceptibility to infections and a variety of symptoms, including possibly polycythemia.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease
diagnoses.description: A term for two conditions (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis) that are characterized by chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. Symptoms can include severe diarrhea, pain, fatigue, and weight loss. Flushing and ulcers can be a part of the symptom complex in Crohn's disease.

diagnoses.name: Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder where one or more tumors form in the pancreas or the upper part of the small intestine (duodenum). These tumors produce large amounts of the hormone gastrin, leading to excessive stomach acid, causing peptic ulcers.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) damages the immune system and interferes with the body's ability to fight the organisms that cause disease. It can lead to the syndrome known as Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS). Patients are at increased risk of severe infections, including opportunistic infections not commonly seen in individuals with intact immune systems.

diagnoses: Diabetes mellitus type 1 (for hypoglycemia, assuming insufficient management)
Vasculitis (can lead to aneurysms and eosinophilia)
Atopic Dermatitis (linked with eosinophilia and xerosis)
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE, can cause Lymphadenopathy)

diagnoses.name: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: ADHD can manifest as hyperactivity, one of the given symptoms. While it does not directly cause the other symptoms listed, individuals with ADHD may have co-occurring conditions.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: This is a group of disorders that affect connective tissues and can lead to symptoms such as hypermobility. Some types may increase the risk of hemorrhoids due to connective tissue weakness.

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: This bleeding disorder can lead to thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) and could potentially increase the risk of hemorrhoids due to bleeding tendencies.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: This autoimmune disorder increases the risk of thromboembolic diseases. It can indirectly cause thrombocytopenia and other symptoms might be seen in complex cases.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition affecting connective tissue, leading to symptoms like hypermobility. It’s less directly associated with the other listed symptoms but could have related complications.

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhagic Disease of the Newborn
diagnoses.description: This is a rare condition leading to bleeding issues such as thrombocytopenia. The condition is primarily in neonates, making it less relevant for the general population.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease
diagnoses.description: Conditions like Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis can contribute to hemorrhoids due to inflammation of the digestive tract, and might also impact oral health leading to oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder affecting multiple parts of the body, including the mouth, leading to oral pain. It may also be associated with thromboembolic events.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Liver Disease
diagnoses.description: Liver dysfunction can lead to thrombocytopenia, hemorrhoids due to increased pressure in the portal vein, and might have implications leading to hyperactivity in exceptional cases.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immune Thrombocytopenia
diagnoses.description: A disorder that can cause thrombocytopenia. While primarily targeting platelet counts, patients may experience a broad range of symptoms, including some listed.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid storm
diagnoses.reasoning: Combination of hyperthermia, palpitations, and abnormal electrolytes can indicate a thyroid storm, especially in patients with a history of hyperthyroidism.

diagnoses.name: Sepsis
diagnoses.reasoning: Hyperthermia and abnormal electrolytes might suggest an infectious cause such as sepsis, especially if there is a source of infection.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.reasoning: Diarrhea and abnormal electrolytes are common in gastroenteritis. In severe cases, hyperthermia and dehydration could lead to palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.reasoning: Diarrhea and abnormal electrolytes can lead to dehydration, which can cause palpitations and exacerbate obstructive sleep apnea by thickening the blood.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.reasoning: A rare tumor of the adrenal gland that can cause hyperthermia, palpitations, and abnormal electrolytes due to excessive catecholamine release.

diagnoses.name: Cardiac arrhythmia
diagnoses.reasoning: Palpitations suggest an arrhythmia, which can also cause abnormal electrolytes and, in severe cases, could be associated with fever if there is systemic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Drug reaction or toxicity
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain medications or toxic substances can induce hyperthermia, palpitations, diarrhea, and abnormal electrolytes.

diagnoses.name: Adrenal insufficiency
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause hyperthermia, abnormal electrolytes (especially sodium and potassium), and could indirectly contribute to palpitations and exacerbation of sleep apnea symptoms through overall body weakness and instability.

diagnoses.name: Electrolyte imbalance
diagnoses.reasoning: Primary cause like severe electrolyte imbalance can present with palpitations, hyperthermia, and diarrhea, also affecting sleep due to muscle spasms or cramps.

diagnoses.name: Heart failure
diagnoses.reasoning: Can manifest as palpitations due to arrhythmias, and in advanced stages, can lead to abnormal electrolytes and contribute to obstructive sleep apnea by fluid retention causing upper airway obstruction.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Conditions
diagnoses.rationale: Characteristics like leukocytosis and increased immunoglobulins can indicate chronic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Symptoms such as increased immunoglobulins and leukocytosis may point towards an autoimmune etiology.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Diseases
diagnoses.rationale: Leukocytosis, alongside symptoms like Otitis externa, may suggest an ongoing infection.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.rationale: Blood pressure lability could be an indicator of hypertension or underlying issues with blood pressure regulation.

diagnoses.name: Blepharospasm-related Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Primary or secondary, blepharospasm might relate to neurological conditions.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Diseases
diagnoses.rationale: Increased immunoglobulins could either indicate an immune response or an underlying immunodeficiency, depending on the context.

diagnoses.name: Neurological Conditions
diagnoses.rationale: Blepharospasm may be associated with other neurological symptoms, suggesting a broader neurological condition.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.rationale: Otitis externa and increased immunoglobulins may be signs of allergic reactions.

diagnoses.name: Malignancies
diagnoses.rationale: Leukocytosis can be a presentation in various cancers, often as a paraneoplastic syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Skin and Ear Infections
diagnoses.rationale: Otitis externa indicates an ear infection; the presence of leukocytosis could imply a systemic response to such local infections.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: SLE can lead to a wide range of symptoms including thrombocytopenia, skin rashes, and potentially lymphadenitis. It can also contribute to thromboembolic events due to hyperactivity of the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.reason: Behçet's disease is notable for its symptoms of mouth and genital ulcers, skin rashes, and it can also lead to vascular problems such as thrombosis. It might delay puberty indirectly through systemic inflammation or malnutrition.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reason: HIV/AIDS can cause lymphadenitis, thrombocytopenia, and increase the risk for thromboembolic diseases. It can also result in skin rashes and ulcers due to immunosuppression.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.reason: This is a rare immunodeficiency that can lead to lymphadenitis, skin infections leading to rashes, and delay in puberty. Thrombocytopenia is less directly associated but can occur in the context of infection or inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis
diagnoses.reason: This rare disorder can cause a wide array of symptoms including rashes, lymphadenitis, and ulcers. It can also potentially cause thrombocytopenia through bone marrow involvement and indirectly affect puberty timing.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reason: Sarcoidosis is characterized by the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body, including the lymph nodes, which can cause lymphadenitis. It can also lead to skin symptoms like rashes.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
diagnoses.reason: This condition can lead to rashes (often purpuric), abdominal pain, and kidney issues. It can cause thrombocytopenia and, through systemic inflammation, potentially delay puberty.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reason: Tuberculosis can lead to lymphadenitis, cause skin rashes or ulcers, and in severe cases, might contribute to thrombocytopenia. Thromboembolic disease is less common but can occur in the context of a severe systemic infection.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.reason: Some types of leukemia can present with thrombocytopenia, lymphadenitis, and a delay in puberty due to its effects on the bone marrow and overall health. Skin manifestations, including rashes, can also be present.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Anticoagulant-Hypoprothrombinemia Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: This rare condition is associated with lupus anticoagulant and can cause thrombocytopenia and increase the risk of thromboembolic events. It is less directly associated with the other symptoms but could potentially explain a complex presentation.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition characterized by high levels of glucose in the blood, which might account for hyperglycemia. Diabetes could indirectly contribute to mood lability due to fluctuations in blood sugar levels. It does not typically cause dyshydrotic eczema, angioedema, or vaginitis directly, but the disorder can alter immune function and skin health.

diagnoses.name: Contact dermatitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction causing skin irritation. It might present as dyshydrotic eczema in some cases. It is not directly associated with mood lability, hyperglycemia, angioedema, or vaginitis but could coexist with these conditions due to shared environmental or allergic triggers.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Idiopathic Urticaria
diagnoses.description: A condition where urticaria (hives) occurs without a known cause, which could be associated with angioedema. Angioedema is a deeper form of urticaria affecting deeper skin layers. There's no direct link to dyshydrotic eczema, hyperglycemia, mood lability, or vaginitis.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age, known to cause hyperglycemia due to insulin resistance. PCOS can also lead to mood lability and is associated with an increased risk of yeast vaginitis. It's less directly linked to dyshydrotic eczema or angioedema but could influence skin conditions.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Dysfunction
diagnoses.description: Both hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism can lead to mood lability and menstrual irregularities, which may indirectly impact the prevalence of vaginitis. Hypothyroidism can also make a person more susceptible to skin conditions, possibly influencing the development of dyshydrotic eczema. However, it's less directly related to angioedema or hyperglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from chronic exposure to high cortisol levels, which can cause hyperglycemia and mood lability. Skin manifestations such as easy bruising and possibly an increased risk of infections might indirectly influence the development of dyshydrotic eczema. It's not directly linked to angioedema or vaginitis.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions where the immune system attacks the body's own tissues, potentially causing a wide range of symptoms including skin manifestations (like dyshydrotic eczema and angioedema), mood lability, and perhaps indirectly contributing to vaginitis due to altered immunity. Certain autoimmune conditions may also have associations with hyperglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Atopic Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic skin condition causing itchy, inflamed skin, which might be misdiagnosed as or co-occur with dyshydrotic eczema. While primarily a skin condition, the discomfort and sleep disruption it causes can contribute to mood lability. It is not directly related to hyperglycemia, angioedema, or vaginitis.

diagnoses.name: Psychological Stress
diagnoses.description: Stress can have a profound impact on physical health, potentially exacerbating or triggering conditions like dyshydrotic eczema, mood lability, and indirectly influencing vaginitis through its effects on hormone levels and immune function. While stress itself does not cause hyperglycemia or angioedema, its effect on the body can exacerbate underlying conditions that do.

diagnoses.name: Hormonal imbalances
diagnoses.description: Imbalances such as those seen in menopause, thyroid disorders, or adrenal gland disorders can lead to a variety of symptoms including mood lability, vaginitis (due to changes in vaginal flora), and potentially exacerbate skin conditions like dyshydrotic eczema. Hyperglycemia can be a feature of some hormonal imbalances, like in the case of insulin resistance.
Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.rationale: Hyperglycemia is a hallmark sign of diabetes mellitus. This condition can also lead to complications such as fibrosis in various organs, and while less common, ocular changes affecting vision.

diagnoses.description: Autoimmune Disorders (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Sjögren's syndrome)
diagnoses.rationale: Autoimmune disorders can cause fibrosis, dysphagia due to involvement of esophageal muscles, and may lead to complications that affect vision. Some autoimmune conditions can also lead to angioedema.

diagnoses.description: Thyroid Disorders (e.g., Graves' Disease)
diagnoses.rationale: Graves' Disease can cause hyperglycemia, eye symptoms due to thyroid eye disease, and in some cases, fibrosis. Angioedema can be a rare complication of autoimmune thyroid disease.

diagnoses.description: Amyloidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Amyloidosis can cause systemic symptoms including fibrosis of various organs, dysphagia due to gastrointestinal involvement, and can indirectly affect blood glucose levels. Vision problems can occur if there is amyloid deposition in ocular structures.

diagnoses.description: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.rationale: Scleroderma can lead to fibrosis of the skin and internal organs, including the esophagus causing dysphagia, and can affect blood vessels leading to problems with vision. However, direct links to hyperglycemia and angioedema are less common.

diagnoses.description: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily presents with angioedema but can also lead to dysphagia when the throat is affected. It does not usually directly cause hyperglycemia, fibrosis or vision problems but might coexist with other conditions that do.

diagnoses.description: Acromegaly
diagnoses.rationale: Acromegaly can cause hyperglycemia due to insulin resistance, soft tissue swelling leading to visual problems, and can sometimes lead to angioedema-like symptoms. Fibrosis and dysphagia are less directly associated but can occur.

diagnoses.description: Malignancies (e.g., Lymphoma)
diagnoses.rationale: Certain cancers like lymphoma can lead to systemic symptoms including hyperglycemia (Paraneoplastic syndrome), fibrosis of various organs, and can have ocular manifestations. Angioedema and dysphagia can be symptoms or occur due to treatment side effects.

diagnoses.description: Gastrointestinal Disorders (e.g., Achalasia, Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease)
diagnoses.rationale: These conditions directly cause dysphagia and can lead to esophageal fibrosis over time. They are less likely to cause hyperglycemia, angioedema, or vision problems but are important considerations based on the symptom of dysphagia.

diagnoses.description: Neuromuscular Disorders (e.g., Myasthenia Gravis)
diagnoses.rationale: Myasthenia Gravis can lead to dysphagia and might cause difficulty focusing vision due to muscle weakness. It doesn't directly cause hyperglycemia, fibrosis, or angioedema but can coexist with other conditions that do.

diagnoses.description: Behçet's disease
diagnoses.details: Behçet's disease, a rare disorder that causes blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, can lead to symptoms such as ulcers in the mouth and elsewhere, and might contribute to increased susceptibility to infections due to inflammation or complications related to its treatment.

diagnoses.description: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.details: SLE is an autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems in the body, causing a wide range of symptoms including increased susceptibility to infections, lymphadenitis, and oral ulcers. Dyslipidemia and occasional menstrual irregularities or dysmenorrhea could be part of or exacerbated by SLE.

diagnoses.description: Crohn's Disease
diagnoses.details: This is an inflammatory bowel disease that can cause ulcers throughout the gastrointestinal tract, leading to increased risk of infections. Though not directly causing dysmenorrhea, inflammation and other systemic effects could exacerbate menstrual pain.

diagnoses.description: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.details: A bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs but can also spread to lymph nodes (causing lymphadenitis) and elsewhere in the body, leading to increased susceptibility to infection and potential development of ulcers.

diagnoses.description: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.details: HIV affects the immune system, significantly increasing susceptibility to infections. People with HIV/AIDS can also experience lymphadenitis and ulcers. Dyslipidemia is a common complication due to either the infection itself or the antiretroviral therapy.

diagnoses.description: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disease that destroys the glands that produce tears and saliva, causing dry mouth and eyes, which can lead to the development of ulcers. It can also cause lymphadenitis and increase the risk of lymphoma, thus increasing susceptibility to infection.

diagnoses.description: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the joints but can also cause systemic symptoms, including increased susceptibility to infections, lymphadenitis, and, through systemic inflammation, potentially exacerbate dyslipidemia.

diagnoses.description: Lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.details: An inflammatory disease caused when the immune system attacks its own tissues. It can cause severe symptoms, including dysmenorrhea, dyslipidemia, ulcers, lymphadenitis, and increase susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.description: Polyarteritis nodosa
diagnoses.details: A rare autoimmune disease characterized by swollen and tender blood vessels that can lead to organ damage. Symptoms can include ulcers, hypertension (which could be linked to systemic effects involving dyslipidemia), and increased susceptibility to infection.

diagnoses.description: Vasculitis
diagnoses.details: Vasculitis encompasses a group of disorders that involve inflammation of the blood vessels, which can cause symptoms including ulcers, increased susceptibility to infections, and can potentially disturb various body systems leading to symptoms like dyslipidemia.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Viral upper respiratory infection
diagnoses.rationale: Common cause of laryngitis and lymphadenitis, often presenting with throat discomfort and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety or Stress-related disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Stress and anxiety can trigger or exacerbate conditions like takotsubo cardiomyopathy and contribute to dyspnea.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune diseases
diagnoses.rationale: Certain autoimmune conditions can explain a wide range of symptoms, including laryngitis (as part of a multi-organ involvement), lymphadenitis, dyspnea, and potentially contributing to miscarriage.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial infection
diagnoses.rationale: Secondary bacterial infection might complicate an initial viral infection, leading to more severe symptoms including laryngitis and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Hormonal imbalances
diagnoses.rationale: Conditions such as thyroid disorders can contribute to dyspnea, potentially impact cardiac function, and have been linked to miscarriage risks.

diagnoses.name: Cardiovascular disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Underlying or undiagnosed heart conditions, including but not limited to takotsubo cardiomyopathy, can cause dyspnea.

diagnoses.name: Chronic stress
diagnoses.rationale: Long-term stress can lead to a variety of physical conditions, including takotsubo cardiomyopathy and potentially complicating pregnancies.

diagnoses.name: Psychogenic dyspnea
diagnoses.rationale: Also known as 'hyperventilation syndrome,' can occur in the absence of lung pathology, often related to anxiety or panic disorders.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatologic diseases
diagnoses.rationale: Diseases such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis could potentially explain a combination of lymphadenitis, cardiac phenomena, and possibly impact on pregnancy.

diagnoses.name: Infectious mononucleosis
diagnoses.rationale: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, can present with laryngitis, significant lymphadenitis, and fatigue, among other symptoms.

diagnoses: Eating Disorders (e.g., Anorexia Nervosa, Bulimia Nervosa)

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Viral infections can lead to swollen lymph nodes (lymphadenitis), seizures (depending on the virus affecting the central nervous system), otitis externa (as some viruses can cause ear infections), and headaches.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain bacterial infections can cause lymphadenitis, potentially lead to sepsis or meningitis (which can cause seizures), contribute to otitis externa, and be a primary cause of periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Caused by the Borrelia burgdorferi bacterium, Lyme disease can lead to lymphadenitis, neurological problems (including seizures), and headaches. It's less directly associated with otitis externa or periodontal disease but affects multiple body systems.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: HIV infection can cause lymphadenitis, neurological complications that might lead to seizures, and is associated with various opportunistic infections that could relate to the symptoms listed, including periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reasoning: TB can cause lymphadenitis (scrofula), and in severe cases, CNS involvement can lead to seizures. TB-associated headache can occur in miliary disease or TB meningitis. It is less directly linked to otitis externa and periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.reasoning: Secondary syphilis can cause lymphadenopathy and may have neurological involvement leading to seizures in tertiary syphilis. Syphilis can also contribute to oral health issues, potentially impacting periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Herpes Simplex Virus
diagnoses.reasoning: Herpes simplex can cause lymphadenitis, and when affecting the brain (encephalitis), can lead to seizures. While it typically causes oral or genital lesions, it could potentially exacerbate or be related to periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.reasoning: Measles can cause lymphadenitis, and rare complications include seizures from measles encephalitis. While primarily known for its rash and respiratory symptoms, it can cause ear infections (otitis media, potentially leading to externa) and has been linked to general oral health issues.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, mononucleosis can present with significant lymphadenitis, headache, and in rare cases, seizures. It's less directly associated with otitis externa or periodontal disease but affects general health.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Poorly controlled diabetes can lead to a weakened immune system, increasing the risk for infections like otitis externa and periodontal disease. Diabetes is a risk factor for seizures in the presence of hypoglycemia or ketoacidosis.

diagnoses: Neurologic manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency
Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (formerly Churg-Strauss Syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Diabetes Mellitus can cause hyperglycemia and may also affect fertility due to its impacts on overall health, hormonal balance, and possible complications like erectile dysfunction in men and ovulatory issues in women.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myelomonocytic Leukemia
diagnoses.reasoning: A type of leukemia that can cause monocytosis, an increase in monocytes, a type of white blood cell. This condition wouldn't directly cause the other symptoms but could explain the increase in monocytes.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reasoning: PCOS can lead to infertility in women and is often associated with insulin resistance, which can result in hyperglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Though primarily known for causing vasculitis, Behçet's Disease can present with skin lesions that might be confused with angiomata. The disease could theoretically impact fertility and has been associated with blood sugar issues.

diagnoses.name: Metabolic Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: A cluster of conditions including high blood sugar (hyperglycemia), which increases the risk of diabetes, and can indirectly affect fertility. Metabolic syndrome doesn't directly cause otitis externa or angiomata, but the interconnected health issues could lead to systemic complications.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: A disease involving abnormal collections of inflammatory cells (granulomas) that could form in various body parts, potentially explaining angiomata. Sarcoidosis can occasionally lead to changes in blood sugar levels and could indirectly affect fertility.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Cushing's Syndrome can lead to hyperglycemia due to elevated levels of cortisol, and can also cause fertility issues. It doesn’t directly cause monocytosis, otitis externa, or angiomata but has a broad range of systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: HIV/AIDS can cause a wide range of immunological abnormalities including monocytosis. It can indirectly affect fertility, contribute to the development of diabetes, and cause a variety of skin conditions.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reasoning: TB can cause systemic symptoms including monocytosis. TB doesn't directly cause infertility, hyperglycemia, or angiomata, but it's a systemic disease that can have widespread effects on the body.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Infections
diagnoses.reasoning: While not a single diagnosis, chronic infections can cause monocytosis, impact fertility, and may relate to hyperglycemia as part of a wider inflammatory or infectious process. Though less likely, chronic infections can also lead to skin conditions misidentified as angiomata.

diagnoses: Eating Disorders (e.g., Bulimia or Binge Eating Disorder)
Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal Infections (PANDAS)

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which there is a deficiency of red cells or of haemoglobin in the blood, resulting in pallor and tiredness.

diagnoses.name: Gastritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the lining of the stomach, which can cause dyspepsia.

diagnoses.name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition where open sores develop on the inside lining of your stomach and the upper portion of your small intestine, leading to dyspepsia.

diagnoses.name: Essential Hypertension
diagnoses.description: A common condition of unknown cause that results in high blood pressure and blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.description: A rare, usually benign tumor that develops in the center of the adrenal gland, causing excessive production of adrenaline. This leads to severe hypertension and blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
diagnoses.description: A common, chronic, and long-lasting disorder in which a person has uncontrollable, reoccurring thoughts (obsessions) and/or behaviors (compulsions) that he or she feels the urge to repeat over and over.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A type of anemia caused by a lack of iron, leading to a decrease in the production of red blood cells, which can result in pallor among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Autonomic Dysfunction
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the autonomic nervous system (ANS) does not work properly. This can affect blood pressure and lead to blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Hypertension
diagnoses.description: High blood pressure caused by another medical condition, such as kidney disease, endocrine disorders, or certain medications.

diagnoses.name: Functional Dyspepsia
diagnoses.description: A term for recurring signs and symptoms of indigestion that have no obvious cause. Functional dyspepsia is common and can be long-lasting.

diagnoses: Hay Fever (Allergic Rhinitis) with Secondary Infection
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Systemic lupus erythematosus (rare cause, can have cutaneous manifestations)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
COPD exacerbation in patients with underlying disease
Systemic lupus erythematosus (as a less common cause)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Allergic Reaction to Food or Drug
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Strokes may cause symptoms such as paralysis, speech difficulties, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines with aura are a type of migraine that involves visual disturbances and other neurological symptoms that appear about 20 to 60 minutes before the actual migraine headache. Symptoms can include phonophobia, visual disturbances, numbness, or speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a ministroke, a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage. Symptoms can include weakness, numbness, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Depending on the location and size of the tumor, it can cause a variety of neurological symptoms, including weakness, numbness, speech difficulties, and sensory problems.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system) that leads to an immune system attack against myelin, the sheath that covers nerve fibers. Symptoms can include numbness, weakness, balance problems, and speech disorders.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Also known as ALS or Lou Gehrig's disease, it is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord. Symptoms include weakness, muscle stiffness, and eventually, difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Certain types of epilepsy can cause aphasia after a seizure.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. Early symptoms can mimic the flu and may progress to include severe headache, stiff neck, sensitivity to light (photophobia), and altered mental status.

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhagic Stroke
diagnoses.description: A hemorrhagic stroke occurs when a blood vessel in your brain leaks or ruptures. Symptoms are similar to other forms of stroke, including sudden numbness or weakness, especially on one side of the body, headache, speech difficulties, and confusion.

diagnoses: Primary angiitis of the central nervous system

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. A stroke is a medical emergency, and prompt treatment is crucial.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers and causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a ministroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to your brain. TIAs are often a warning sign of a future stroke.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant).

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraine with aura is a type of migraine that involves neurological disturbances, such as visual disturbances, sensory symptoms, or speech or language problems, before the headache itself begins.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: Peripheral neuropathy refers to the conditions that result when nerves that carry messages to and from the brain and spinal cord from and to the rest of the body are damaged or diseased.

diagnoses.name: Ménière's Disease
diagnoses.description: Ménière's disease is a disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In most cases, Ménière's disease affects only one ear.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: Acoustic neuroma is a noncancerous and usually slow-growing tumor that develops on the main nerve leading from your inner ear to your brain. Pressure from the tumor can cause hearing loss, ringing in your ear (tinnitus), and imbalance.

diagnoses.name: Bell's Palsy
diagnoses.description: Bell's palsy causes sudden, temporary weakness in your facial muscles. This makes half of your face appear to droop. Your smile is one-sided, and your eye on that side resists closing.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barre syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: SLE can manifest with a wide range of symptoms including seizures, thrombocytopenia, and less commonly pericardial effusion. Dermatologic manifestations might mimic lichen planus.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.reason: This disease can present with features of several systemic autoimmune diseases, including lupus, with symptoms such as thrombocytopenia and pericardial effusion. Dermatological and neurologic manifestations can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.reason: Scleroderma might present with telangiectasias and pericardial effusion. Thrombocytopenia and seizures are less common but can occur in severe disease.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.reason: Features can include skin manifestations that may resemble lichen planus and systemic symptoms such as pericardial effusion. Thrombocytopenia is less common.

diagnoses.name: Primary Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: This condition can lead to systemic complications including neurological manifestations (seizures) and hematological abnormalities (thrombocytopenia).

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: While not commonly associated with seizures or thrombocytopenia, some types of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome can present with telangiectasias and other vascular abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: This disorder is characterized by thrombosis and pregnancy morbidity in the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies. It can cause thrombocytopenia and neurological manifestations including seizures.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.reason: Certain types of vasculitis can cause neurological symptoms (seizures), skin manifestations, and other systemic symptoms including pericardial effusion and thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reason: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including severe skin rash, joint pain, thrombocytopenia, seizures, and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planus and Lichenoid Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Though primarily a skin disease, lichen planus can be associated with systemic diseases. Its presence alongside other symptoms warrants further investigation for an underlying systemic cause.

diagnoses: Vasculitis (specifically microscopic polyangiitis or polyarteritis nodosa)
Hepatitis B or C with associated cryoglobulinemia

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the skin, joints, kidneys, heart, and lungs. Symptoms such as arthropathy, pericardial effusion, and proteinuria are commonly seen in SLE.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune rheumatic disease characterized by hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. Scleroderma can also affect internal organs and can cause symptoms such as telangiectasias, proteinuria, and arthropathy.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that exhibits features of three other connective tissue diseases — lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis — including symptoms like arthropathy, proteinuria, and potentially pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. While not commonly associated with pericardial effusion or telangiectasias, RA can lead to arthropathy and rarely proteinuria due to renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome)
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation and can cause telangiectasias. It's less commonly associated with the other symptoms but can occasionally lead to issues like proteinuria through renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. It's not typically associated with pericardial effusion or proteinuria but can lead to arthropathy and, less commonly, to telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.description: A serious blood vessel disease where small and medium-sized arteries become swollen and damaged. While it can cause symptoms like arthropathy and proteinuria, pericardial effusion is less common but possible.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. Though primarily affecting the skin and muscles, it can sometimes lead to complications like arthropathy and, in rare cases, to proteinuria or even pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue, contributing to skeletal structure abnormalities, potentially leading to arthropathy, and in rare instances, to cardiovascular complications like pericardial effusion but less likely proteinuria or telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the kidneys caused by Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), leading to proteinuria. While it's focused on kidney involvement, patients may also experience symptoms related to SLE like arthropathy and possibly pericardial effusion.

diagnoses: Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia (as a secondary condition)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation of various parts of the body. It can manifest with skin rashes, joint pain, kidney involvement (proteinuria), neurological manifestations (such as mononeuritis multiplex), and hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that involve inflammation of blood vessels. Specific types like cryoglobulinemic vasculitis can show symptoms like rash, peripheral neuropathy (which can appear as mononeuritis multiplex), and kidney involvement. Hemolytic anemia may also be a feature.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory autoimmune disorder affecting the joints and may present with extra-articular features like skin ulcers or nodules (panniculitis), vasculitis, and hematological abnormalities including hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash. While not commonly associated with hemolytic anemia or proteinuria, in severe systemic cases, multiorgan involvement can occur.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, it is a form of vasculitis that can cause asthma, eosinophilia, and neuropathy including mononeuritis multiplex. Kidney involvement and skin manifestation are also possible.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.description: A serious blood vessel disease characterized by inflammation of small and medium-sized arteries, leading to tissue damage. Symptoms can include rash, muscle and joint pain, kidney damage, and neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. Skin manifestations (including panniculitis), neuropathy, and less commonly hemolytic anemia can be seen.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer of the lymphatic system. It can cause a variety of systemic symptoms including skin manifestations, peripheral neuropathy, hemolytic anemia, and in advanced stages, kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Leishmaniasis
diagnoses.description: A disease caused by the bite of an infected sand fly. It can cause skin sores, and in its visceral form, can affect internal organs like the spleen and liver, potentially leading to hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: HIV-associated nephropathy
diagnoses.description: A condition associated with HIV infection, leading to kidney disease (proteinuria) and can have dermatological manifestations, and in severe cases, system-wide effects including hematological abnormalities.

diagnoses: Viral Infections (such as HIV, Hepatitis C)
Chronic Kidney Disease related to autoimmune disorders
